document.text: Winners of the 1965 Betty  Crocker Homemaker of Tomor-  row award at Carver-Price High School is Georgia Walker. She scored highest in her school in a written homemaking examination administered to ov- er a half-million senior girls throughout the country on Dec.  1, and remains in contention for j scholarship grants ranging from 500 to 5,000. Test papers of all school win- i ers in the state are being judged competitively. From this, th e State Homemaker of Tomorrow will be named. Following her selection, t h e State Homemaker of Tomorrow, together with a school advisor, will join winners and advisors from each of the 49 other states and the District of Columbia in an expense - paid educational tour of Colonial Williamsburg, Va., Washington, D.C., and New York City.

document.text: When Carver-Price High School was burglarized recently, thieves made off with 120 in March of Dimes collections. They pushed the dimes from the cardboard collectors. That deft the Negro people of the county on a spot as to their contribution to the March of Dimes. But they re newed their efforts, and this week they turned the sum of 192 over to the committee.

document.text: We rare happy to report that Phillip Haskins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson N. Haskins, Route 2, of the Springfield community, was promoted to sergeant Janu ary 10, 1962, at Fort Hood, Texas, vhere he is serving with the 1st Armoured Division. Specialist Has kins, a gunner in the divisions Howitzer Batlxtllion, 6th Artillery entered the Army in July, 19i5l9 and has served in the Far East. Haskins is a 1959 graduate of the Carver-Price High School. Impressive services were held at the Galilee Baptist Church last First Sunday morning, at both the morning and evening services. The pastor of the chiujrch delivered the morning sermon, from the subject Genuine Beauty. All pdesent en joyed the message. Special music was rendered by tihe senior choir. Several visitors attended the serv ice. The offering for the day very good. The 730 service was sponsored by Mrs. Bernice Lawir.g, a leader in the special Well Fund drive.The Rev. Johnnie Paigg was the guest speaker. Special music was render ed by the Junior Oho in. of the church. Tbg Promise Land Baptist Church presented plans for a special drive The Twelve Sons of Jacob Ral ly. to come to a close on1 the fourth Sunday in March. The fol lowing -men of the church will take part in the rally Deacons Em- niette Fleshmar., Stewart Robinson William Hancock C. M. Harvey, Virgil Fleshman, and Messrs. Sam Fleshman, John LeGrande, Weldon Flestoman, Lloyd Forest, Jasper Thornton, Lindsey Marshall, and Clarence Wheeler. Mr. Lindsey Marshall and Mrs. Helen Callaham Duigiud were mar ried lat the home of Rev. and Mrs. R. Qi. Laiwing lajst Saturday eve ning at 745. Tihg ceneimony was witi.-essed iby relatives and friends, The newlyweds will, make their home in the Promise Land com munity. Professor E. T. Johnson has been appointed as acting principal of the Carver-Price High iSdhool. Mr. Johnson has taught at the Carver- Price High School for over twen ty years. H e has taught history, social studies, and French, and he has served as the school treasurer. Mr. George Tibbs was stricken at his homg last Saturday morning. He is receiving treatment at the home of his daughter, Mrs. C. D Beasley. Mrs. Nannie Wright is undergo ing special treatment in the Lynch, burg General Hospital.

A special planning meeting of the Negro Organization Society of Vir ginia met at the Carver-Price High School Sunday at 4 P. M. to discuss plans for the annual meeting of the organization here in November. The president oef the Organization, the treasurer and executive secretary of Hampton, Va. presented plans for conducting thé meeting and served as consultants to the local commit tee members. The annual meeting will be held here Nov. 8 and- 9. Regular preaching services were held at the First Baptist Church last Sunday morning. In the absence of the pastor, Rev. Jordan, who is on vacation, a young student from Virginia Seminary and college con ducted the services in a very fine manner. He will return on the sec ond Sunday in October. The church choir rendered special music. The offering was very good. Regular evening services were held at the Mount Shiloh Baptist Church last Sunday evening at 730. The pastor of the church officiated. Hubert Watkins left Tuesday for New York, where he has acepted a teaching position. Rev. and Mrs. R. Q. Lawing spent Monday evening in Petersburg. Mrs. Catherine OCoçner, of New York is spending some time here as the guest of her sister, Mrs. Lucy Tibbs. Orison Nowlin, of Baltimore, spent his vacation here as the guest of his mother, Mrs. Emma Nowlin. Mr. Tom Kelso spent the week end in Baltimore with relatives and friends.

document.text: Tumer and bara Reed, Russel Helen Bagby. The Carver-Price High School Panthers played two games last week and won the game with Car ter G. Woodson at Dillwyn 41-35, on the losers court, but lost in Waynesboro 60 - 53 in a conference game. In the Woodson- game, the lead changed often but the Panthers put on a rally in the final two min utes winning going away. James Gafford was the high scorer with 17 points, followed by Isaac Trent with 10 points The Waynesboro game was decid ed in the fourth quarter when the winners made 19 points to the Pan- tres 11 points. The Panthers held a 42-41 lead after the end of the third quarter. Again the Panthers were led by their high - scoring ace Janies Gafford, with 29 points. On Friday, the Panthers will play host to Central High, of Amherst. Carver-Price defeated the Amherst  quintet in Amherst by a 37 - 34 score on January 21. Come out and cheer our team to victory. We close with this thought for the week I ask and wish not to appear ilkjore haeuteous, rich or gay Lord, make me wiser every year, And better every day.

document.text: There will be a county-wide meet ing at Carver-Price High School on Frida-i, Feb. 4 at 930 A. M. This is an important meeting, as an official from the Social Security Office will be present and explain the new So cial Security rulings. A large crowd attended the Cornerstone Baptist Sunday School Union Sunday, Jan. 31. The pro gram consisted of a general Sunday School Department, with teachers for each grade. The lesson was then reviewed by the president, and was enjoyed by the group. Business ses sion and then an enjoyable program was given by the youth of the Sun day Schools. A sermon by the pas tor of the Beautiful Zion Church Rev. B. A. Carrington. The same of ficers were elected again. Pres., Rev. T. M. Venerable Sec., Mrs. L. M. Canada Asst. Sec., Mrs. L. M. Robinson Treas, Mr. J. Haskins Pi anist, Mrs. H. Miller. Rev. Wilson from Beautiful Plane Church and Rev. R. Q. Lawing were among the visitors. A nice sum of 93.67 was raised. Will meet next with the Mt. Zion Church. Rev. H. R. D. Vener able is the pastor. A song program by the Gospel Four Singers, of Lyncburg, was well attended at the St. Luke Baptist Church Sunday, beginning at 800 oclock., given by Mr. Wilson Mason.

document.text: There will be a county-wide meet ing at Carver-Price High School auditorium on Friday, February 4 , 1955, at 930 A. M. The public is invited to hear the speakers. We will hear Mr. James Dinwiddie, who will speak on the new .Social Se curity rulings. All of us should ben efit from this message, as the new rulings will give many of us bene fits that we can and should qualify for. The second speaker will be Mr. A. H. Furh, from Washington, who will speak on Farm Credit. Mr. Furh has been with us before, and many people have requested that he re turn. RememberFebruary 4 , 1955 at 930 A. M., at the High School, be sure and plan to attend this meet ing. Your Farm Agents Office has been moved to a new location. It is now across from the Freezer Lock er plant on Court Street. G. L. James, Farm Agent.

document.text: Theodore W. Mabry, above, looks over the new addition to Carver-Price High School. The School Board has announced his appointment as principal. Carver-Price will have thirty teachers plus Mabry on opening day, Sept. 2. The county elementary schools, Mt. Airy and Stonewall, have been con solidated with Carver-Price because of the eleven classroom addition. The new principal graduated from high school in McKenny, Virginia. He received his Bachelor and Masters degrees from Virginia State College, Petersburg, plus ad vanced study in administration at the University of Virginia. Mabry taught 13 years in Amelia County Schools and for the past three years has been principal of a combined elementary- high school, Mathews. His wife will teach 6th grade at Carver- Price this session. The Mabrys have two sons, ages five and three.

document.text: The wedding of Miss Averdia Megginson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hezekiah Megginnson, and Ru dolph Tibbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Tibbs took place at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Beasley Saturday, March 19 at 8 P. M. The Rev. R. Q. Lawing, pastor of the groom performed the marriage cere mony. The home was decorated with white gladiolias, bridal wreaths, waxy snapdragons and lillies, flank ed by tall white candles in crystal candle sticks. This gave a beautiful background. Members of the im mediate families and a large num ber of friends were present to wit ness the ceremony. The bride wore a lovely baby pink chiffon dress fashioned over satin. The bodice was snugged with baller ina length skirt. The finger tip French illusion veil was attached to a hat of matching flowers. She car ried a white orchid corsage on a showered white prayer book. The maid of honor, a sister of the bride, Miss Annie L. Megginson wore a silk crystalllette dress of aqua blue with harmonizing accessories. Mr. George Stephens, of Balti more, Maryland, was the best man. The bride and groom were showered with many beautiful gifts. The re ception was held following the wed ding. The groom is a 1954 graduate of Virginia State College and is em ployed as a research specialist for the United States government in Frederick, Md. The bride is a former student of the Carver-Price High School. After a weeks vacation here the newlyweds will live in Frederick, Md. Impressive services were held at the Galilee Baptist Church last Sun day morning. The pastor delivered a special sermon on the subject, The highway of life. All present en joyed the message. A special appeal for the Red Cross was made at the close of the service by Miss H. B. Stevens. The offering for the day was very good. A large crowd attended the an nual Womans Day program at the Mount Shiloh Baptist Church last Sunday at 3 P. M. The following pro gram was enjoyed by all who at tended. Singing by the audience. Scripture reading by Mrs. S. J . Flowers. Prayer, Mrs. Mary Tanner. Welcome address, Miss Novella Hicks. Response, Mrs. Mattie West.

document.text: The Town of Appomattox is to get two important sidewalk projects as the result of town approval of an agreement with the State Highway Department. Eight tenths of a mile of sidewalk are involved in two pro jects. The Town Council at its re gular monthly meeting on Monday night approved the proposal. The sidewalks will be build along Routes 460 and 131. The Route 460 project calls for approximately .43 mile sidewalk, ex tending on the north side, from the intersection of Church Street, to the driveway at the Carver-Price High School. The project on Route 131 Court Street will extend on the west side from the intersection of Virginia Ave. to approximately opposite the E. T. Guill Service Station next to 460. Under the agreement, the work will be supervised by the State High way Department, with the State and the Town each bearing one-half the cost. It is understood that all rights o f way have been secured, and that the State will offer the sidewalk projects immediately for bids, and that actual work will begin with the hope of com pletion before winter weather. These projects have long -been needed in Appomattox. The sidewalk on Route 460 will be a great safety measure for personnel at the Appo mattox Garmeift Company, Inc., and for the students at the Carver-Price High School.

document.text: The members of the Junior j Class of the Carver-Price High School of Appomattox, were ask ed by their sponsor to join to gether in observing the true  spirit of Christmas in all its j beauty and significance. The class sponsored another project instead of the annual contribu tion for personal Christmas bags this year. They agreed to each buy the Christmas dinners of two chil dren in Grades 1 through 12, who perhaps were not financially able to buy their own. Other peo ple hearing of the class project also made donations to help the Juniors to buy dinners for more children. Some of the Juniors, them selves, usually bring their lunch es from home but they are un selfish enough to sacrifice fifty cents to see to it that two chil dren will eat a well-balanced and a deliciously prepared dinner at Christmas time. document.text: The following information was released by the Division Superinten dent of Schools of Appomattox County, Mr. J. A. Burke, covering operation of the schools for the ses sion of 1951-52. It should be of in terest to all citizens. The estimated value of school sites, buildings, furniture and fix tures, and school buses excluding the new Carver-Price High School Building which was not in operation during the last session, was 785,- 450.00. The total enrollment for all the schools of the County was 2,133. Out of this number, 1,920 children attended school every day. A total of 213 children were absent each day, eithsfrom sickness-or other causes. This number of absentees represents a definite loss to the pupils and also to the County. Un fortunately, many causes of absences did not come under the head of ex cusable absences. Of the 2,133 enrolled, 1,820 pass ed their grades, 225 were retained in the same grades and 88 pupils dropped out of school entirely. document.text: The Bloodmobile will come to Ap pomattox Oct. 30 to collect a quota of 135 pints of blood. The basement of Liberty Baptist Church will be used for this visit as the high school cafeteria will not be available on this school day. Mrs. J. R. Lawson, chairman of the Blood Program for Appomattox County, and J. Newton Jennings, blood donor chairman, met with a group of workers in the Carver-Price High School Tuesday afternoon to outline the less than three-week drive to sign up a minimum of 160 pros pective donors, in order to secure 135 pints after a certain percentage is screened. This will be the first visit since June 15, and it is believed that citizens will welcome the opportunity to give their blood to those who are in dire need of it. Blood donar cards will be placed in each of the banks and at the post office, and it is hoped that donors will ask for them and sign without being  personally contacted, said Mr. Jennings.

document.text: Seventy five pupils were enrolled at the beginning of the term . The enrollment increased as the one-room schools in the county were . closed, and teachers and students were transferred to the Appomattox County Training School. Using two buildings, the 1932 33 session of the Appo mattox County Training School opened with four teachers. The olid three-room elementary school was renovated into a new agricultural department undffliTqireCwon bttho Rev. R. Q. Lawing. The- Works Progress Administr a t i o n WPA constructed a new agriculture building which was used for,several years. The Rev. Jordan developed the schools first football team, pole vaulting team, track and high jumping teams. The Home Economics De partment rhs developed by the elementary teachers who in cluded sewing and cooking in their curriculum. A new department was built in the early 1940s. It was in May of 1933 that the first graduation exercise was held. The present building was completed in 1950-51. Upon approval of. the School Board, the name of the school was changed to Carver-Price High School at the . dedication exercises in 1952 in honor of Mrs. M. J. Price, Supervisor. The following principals have served the Rev. A. E. Jordan, C. A. Pennihgton, Sam E. Ewell, James Thomas Butler, Richard E. Patrick, E. T. Johnson, Maurice M. Robinson, T. W. Mabry, and L. Alvin Beamon. The county school officials planned reorganization- proce dures which brought about unification in the schools in February of 1970. document.text: Rocks Carver-Price High School STUDENT TEST MAY 20 Major General Lewis B. Hersey, Director of Selective Service, today announced an additional Selective Service Qualification Test to be held May 20 at 1,000 testing centers. This will be a clean-up test for the benefit of students prevented by illness or other emergency from taking the test on April 22 of this year, and for those who failed to make application before the dead line for the April test. General Hershey said he could not emphasise too strongly that stu dents who have a certificate of ad mission for the April 22 test which they failed to use on the assigned date must submit a new application if they wish to take the May 20 test. The old certificate, he point ed out, will not admit a student to the May 20 test. He must se cure a new certificate of admission. Application blanks for the May 20 test may be obtained from the students nearest local board and should be sent as soon as possible to the Educational Tetsing Service, Princeton, New Jersey. .Students who attain a prescrib ed upper class standing or make a score of 70 or better on the May 20 test are eligible for consideration by their local boards for deferment during the next academic year. Lo cal boards are not required to de fer students who meet one or both of their criteria, General Hershey pointed out, but their classifications are subject to appeal.

document.text: Ralph Brunson, executive director of the Metropolitan YMCA in Tennessee, has announced the appointment of Roslyn Robinson as adult program director of the East Family YMCA. Mrs. Robinson is the daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. A. . West, Jr. of Appomattox. She assumed her new duties October 1,1977. Mrs. Robinson has been at j the East Branch since Febr- j uary, said Brunson in making  the anouncement, teaching  swimming to all age levels and i conducting a class combining j movement exploration and  swimming for pre-school chil- j dren. In addition, she has j taught aqua-dynamics to a- dults, directed Kiddy Kamp for ! pre-school children and taught j aerobic dance and womens j fitness programs. Roslyn also taught beginning j gymnastics at the Southwest Y j before going to East. Preceed-1 ing her move to Nashville,  Tennessee she was on the staff  of the Westside YMCA in j . Knoxville and was employed by  the Central Y and University o f1 Tennessee Student AquaticJ Center as a swimming instruc-1 tor. She far excelled the other I applications for this position.  A native of Virginia, she graduated from Carver-Price High School in Appomattox I before graduation from Hamp-  ton Institute where she j majored in health, physical education and recreation. After graduation she enrolled in a program of corrective therapy j at the Veterans Administra-i tion Hospital and received what j was equivalent to six semesteri hours toward a m asters  degree. Although I have only been with the YMCA a short period of time, Roslyn said, I have gamed more knowledge and grown more as an individual in that time than I could have anywhere, doing anything else. I have always enjoyed working with people and at the Y, I realize the full value of relating to peoples needs. My major goal in life is to find not only my own undeveloped talents and realize their full value, but also to help others to realize theirs and put them to effective use, she said. She is married to Larry C. Robinson,  also a native ef Appomattox.

document.text: PAMPLIN - Mrs. Ora Wilsie Womack Smith of Pamplin entered into rest Thursday, May 27 at SL Lukes Hospital, New York City. She was a daughter of the late Martin and Edmonia Womack and the widow of George Smith. Mrs. Smith received her education at Virginia Seminary and College, SL Pauls Insti tute. Lawrenceville, and Vir ginia State College, Peters burg, where she received B.S. and M.A. degrees. Mrs. Smith became a member of Zion Baptist Church in early girlhood and served as church clerk and Sunday school teach for many years. She also was a retired member of the Appomattox High School Carver-Price faculty. Mrs. Smith was widely known and highly esteemed as a most valuable citizen and an energetic religious and civic leader. Mrs. Smith is survived by two brothers, Martin Van Womack of New York City and Robert Womack of Baltimore four sisters, Mrs. Befjha Branford of New York City, Mrs. Aphalia Wood of Pitts burg, Mrs. Geneva Wiggins of Lynchburg and Mrs. Odell Hix of Pamplin six nieces, eight nephews, among them Walter Branford of Yonkers, N.Y. two ybrothers-in-law, John Wood of Pittsburgh and Garfield Hicks of Pamplin and two sisters-in- law, Mrs. Janice  Womack of Baltimore and Mrs. Aleasw Womack of New York City. Funeral services were held Wednesday at 4 p.m. in Zion Baptist Church, Pamplin, with interm ent in the church cemetery. The Rev. L. E. Hankins officiated, assisted by the Revs. R. Q. La wing, James Franklin and J. H. Hendricks. Jeffress Funeral Home, Charlotte Court House, was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: On Tuesday, October 11, Walter Berryman was guest speaker at the Carver-Price High School. Berry man is a former 4-H member, Re gional Delegate, Veteran of World War II and a Senior at Va. State College. He was chosen as an Ex tension Farm Youth Exchange dele gate to Europe. He visited in Eng land, Italy, Wales and France for 5 months. The trip was financed and sponsored by the EFYE program, the Extension Service and the local 4-H clubs of Virginia. j Mr. Berryman showed slide pic tures he had taken while overseas and told of his many experiences with the Engilsh people, their habits, mode of living, their conservation, and methods of farming. He lived with 16 different farm families and visited many of the centuries-old his torical sites. A very interesting statement made was that, the English stop everything for tea. The buses, work in the fields, people in autos, and tea is even served on trains and boats. Berryman said that at no time during his stay in England was I he more than 90 miles from water. I The talk ended with a question and answer period, and Walter Berry-j man, expressed his appreciation to I all those who played a part in mak ing his experiences possible. The 4-H NFA Hog Show and Safi I was held at the livestock market in Lynchburg, on Monday, October 17. I The 4-H boys of Appomattox parti- I pating were Herbert Williams and Otis Walker. These boys showed and sold 5 hogs. Their weights were I 220 pounds, and 185 pounds for I Otis, a pen of three, weighing 575 I pounds, average 192 pounds, for Her- I bert. These animals were raised by 11 these boys especially for this event. I Their goal was 200 pounds within a I six month age and growing period. 11 The boys received 16 cents per 100 11 wt. The totals on sales amounted to 11 156.80. Herbert Williams pen of I three won grand championship of the I show of 50 hogs. His prize was 15. I We are especially proud of these I young men, our future farmers.

document.text: OFF TO WASHINGTON- Boarding their flight, at Youngstown airport with company representative Jim Butcher, communications, are from the right grand prize winer, Kenny Vaughan, and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vaughan. William H. Vaughan is a graduate of Carver-Price High School in Appomattox. The artistic talents of Monica Banaszak Indiana Harbor and William K, Kenny Vaughan Youngstown paid off handsomely. As grand prize winners in the Happy Birthday U.S.A. Bicentennial Art Contest. Monica and Kenny and their families were the companys guests for five action-packed days in Washington. Flying there early on Friday, July 1, the group enjoyed the Bicentennial week end in regal splendor. Traveling by limousine, Monica and Kenny toured everything from Arlington to Watergate. They even dined at the famous San Souci where Mrs. Ford recently held a birthday luncheon for the President. They bid Washington good-by on Monday, July 5th after one last whirl through the Smithsonian Institution.

Miss Walker graduated from Carver-Price High School in 1961 and was graduated from Norfolk State College in 1965. Prior to receiving her Masters Degree, Miss Walker taught in the Business Department in a school in New York City.
